description: From Latin expurgātus, perfect passive participle of expurgō (“purge, cleanse, purify”).

verbs.description: expurgate (third-person singular simple present expurgates, present participle expurgating, simple past and past participle expurgated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To edit out (incorrect, offensive, or otherwise undesirable information) from a book or other publication; to cleanse; to purge.
examples: The publisher decided to expurgate the love scene from the book, to make it more child-friendly.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To undertake editing out incorrect, offensive, or otherwise undesirable information from (a book or other publication); to cleanse; to purge.
examples: The publisher decided to expurgate the book, which meant removing the love scene.
